newsitem.title: TURKEY: Opposition, Kurd group welcome U.S. Iraq strikes.
newsitem.headline: Opposition, Kurd group welcome U.S. Iraq strikes.

text.p: Iraqi opposition and Kurdish groups welcomed U.S. attacks on targets in Iraq on Tuesday, but expressed concern about the possibility of civilian casualties.

"We welcome any action to reverse (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein's invasion of northern Iraq," a spokesman for the Iraqi National Congress (INC) told Reuters. "But we are concerned about civilian casualties. Saddam often puts military facilities in residential areas."
The spokesman said he hoped that the military action be followed by concrete steps, "like extending the no-fly zone or imposing a no armour and heavy weapons zone in northern Iraq".
On Tuesday the United States said it had launched cruise missile attacks against Iraq in retaliation for Iraqi attacks on the Kurdish north.
The Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) faction said it hoped this attack would pave the way for Saddam's downfall.
"We hope it will force Saddam Hussein to withdraw all his attacking forces from Arbil from all the places which they have entered," the PUK's Latif Rashid told Reuters from London.

"This is a first step to undermine Saddam Hussein's regime. We hope this will lead to the fall of Saddam Hussein," he said. "We want the United States and international community to help us get rid of this brutal dictator."
Iraqi forces attacked the northern Iraqi town of Arbil at the weekend, ousting the PUK faction in place there and replacing it with a rival group more favourable to Baghdad.
U.N. officials said Iraqi forces had withdrawn from Arbil but the United States said this was insignificant as tanks were still outside the town.
